instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-0840: What is 820-0840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi, 

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that hat a very small liquid contact, and  has no power. Ampmeter stays black, and i get no voltage on F3000.
<CAPACITOR>C8167</CAPACITOR> was oxidated and i removed (looks that was the only point with liquid contact).

After removing <CAPACITOR>C8167</CAPACITOR>, i notice that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>, on diode mode, and ohm reading oscilates a lot (diode readings oscilates bettwen 0.485 and 0.086. ohm reading oscilates bettwen 45k ohm and 5k ohm).

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: First of all, have you inspected USB-C ports? Are they clean and free from corrosion? If so, what is the resistance to ground on F3000?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: They look clean and F3000 has 2.5K ohm of resistance to ground

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Check diode mode to ground on the CC1/2 pins of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
It looks that <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is shorted.
Diode readings:
<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
CC1=0.041
CC2=0.122

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>:
CC1=0.545
CC2=0.550

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Two bad readings point to bad <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I've replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and now i get 5V on one usb-c port and 5V on F3000. 
However, on the other usb-c port i get black ampmeter, and 0V on F3010, but diode readings on CC1/2 of <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> are the same as <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> (good)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings between <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 on various points; especially the lines connected to J3300.
Also check <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and adjacent components.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
It seams that I have a short in <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>.
<CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> has 0.0006 in diode reading.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Very likely bad <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.
You should remove <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> and test again.
Be aware,  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>  splits into more rails; look at pages 28 and 69.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
After removing <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> the  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>  short is gone, but afetr I replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, now i get 5.15V on both usb-c ports

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Do you get correct LDO rails for <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips now?
Check in voltage and diode mode.

Any other voltages appear on the logic board?
What happens if you connect known good battery, with some charge?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
OK, 
the first <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>) was bad (don't understant why, because the readings were the same as the <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>). After replacing it, it started to work again.
TKS
